postsData.content:
𝗕𝗮𝗹𝗮𝗻𝗰𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗰𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗜𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝗜𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝗻 𝗛𝗲𝗮𝗹𝘁𝗵𝗰𝗮𝗿𝗲 

Today, I’m exploring a counter-intuitive insight for healthcare practices: focusing solely on refining processes without considering innovation can hold back growth and patient care improvements.

In healthcare, efficiency is essential, but over-prioritizing process optimization at the expense of new approaches can impact patient satisfaction and practice growth.

Here’s why balancing improvement with innovation is crucial:

𝟭. 𝗠𝗶𝘀𝘀𝗲𝗱 𝗢𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘁𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗡𝗲𝘄 𝗔𝗽𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗮𝗰𝗵𝗲𝘀

In healthcare, preparing for industry changes-such as advances in telemedicine, AI, or patient engagement tools-requires looking beyond incremental improvements. By staying open to emerging technologies, practices can adapt and leverage new opportunities to improve patient outcomes.

𝟮. 𝗟𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗜𝗻𝗻𝗼𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝗻 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗖𝗮𝗿𝗲

Focusing solely on optimizing existing processes may limit resources for exploring new care methods or adopting advanced tools. Innovation in healthcare is essential to opening up new possibilities for patient engagement, improving outcomes, and delivering personalized care.

𝟯. 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗮𝗱𝘃𝗮𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗴𝗲

In a fast-evolving industry, healthcare practices that only refine internal processes risk falling behind competitors who innovate and implement cutting-edge technology. Patients increasingly look for providers who stay current with medical advancements and patient communication methods.

𝟰. 𝗗𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗣𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗡𝗲𝗲𝗱𝘀

Reliance on past successes can lead to overlooking shifts in patient expectations, such as a desire for more accessible communication or integrated health records. While refining processes enhances efficiency, adapting to new patient demands strengthens retention and satisfaction.

𝟱. 𝗥𝗲𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝗠𝗶𝘀𝗮𝗹𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻

Overinvesting in current processes without reallocating resources to new initiatives can limit potential growth. A balanced approach enables practices to invest wisely in both process refinement and innovative tools that elevate patient care.

𝟲. 𝗟𝗮𝗰𝗸 𝗼𝗳 𝗩𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻

While operational efficiency is necessary, maintaining a strategic vision that includes innovation is key to long-term growth. Practices that balance process improvement with forward-looking initiatives cultivate resilience in an evolving healthcare environment.

In healthcare, a balance of efficient processes and bold innovations is essential for sustainable growth, improved patient care, and patient loyalty.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Balancing process efficiency with innovation is crucial for enhancing patient care and staying competitive in healthcare.

postsData.content:
What is Halo Effect? 

Listening the word "Halo Effect" feels like it's a part of Graphic Designing & Video Editing, right?

Wrong  Halo Effect is actually a psychological concept.


Here's the best way to understand it:

'Cognitive Bias' happens when we judge a person’s entire character based on just one or two qualities.

For example, if you notice one positive trait in someone and assume they are great in every aspect—that’s cognitive bias in action!


It's VERY COMMON in the CORPORATE WORLD

 Have you ever found yourself assuming someone is highly skilled just because they speak confidently That’s the Halo Effect in action!

comments.commentText: Simleen, this is an insightful exploration of the Halo Effect. It's fascinating how our perceptions can be so easily colored by singular traits, especially in professional environments. Your emphasis on mental well-being and self-awareness is crucial in fostering genuine connections. I appreciate how you bring attention to the complexities of human judgment in the corporate world; it's a reminder for us all to look deeper and understand individuals beyond surface qualities.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insight! The Halo Effect is a crucial reminder to evaluate colleagues holistically, not just based on a single trait. Lets stay mindful!

postsData.name:
Jon Leslie 🔵
Jon Leslie 🔵
postsData.content:
How did Agile & Scrum get pigeonholed into only being useful for product delivery? 

Scrum literally has a role titled Product Owner, which encompasses all the responsibilities of a traditional Product Manager and then some.

 The key differentiator being:

The Product Owner bridges the gap between business stakeholders and development, while a traditional Product Manager perpetuates the gap.

 What happened, and how can we fix it?

comments.commentText:
Because it didn't. It was designed to be that way. It was designed as a different kind of project management and has nothing to say about product management - by design.

Product Managers understand the market and business conditions. They are business leaders. Scrum (designed by engineers) wanted Product Managers all for themselves in the project context severing their link to the business and market context by only giving them capacity for the project context.

"Scrum has been driven from the (software) development community. I think this causes us to see the Product Owner in our eyes. What can they do to help us do better. We haven’t seen them through their eyes, responsible for a product, thinking about how we in development can collaborate with the PO to help her do her job better.

The people in Product Management and customers have caught on. They have realized that we want them for ourselves, to help us do our work. They have fled, leaving behind a largely eviscerated Product Owner position, the Product Owner/Business Analyst. Of course, this simply reinforces waterfall, where someone is between the developers and the person in charge of the product and its use." - Ken Schwaber

Russell Ashby Thanks Russell. Ken Schwaber pretty much sums up the situation in two paragraphs. 

Maybe the ideal of the Product Owner can only exist in very small product startups?
Or with the roles that people think a Scrum team doesn't need because the PO can do it all. Business Analyst, Project Management e.t.c

I'm really enjoying your Agile & Scrum posts, Jon. I think they will open a lot of eyes to some silly, if not shady, usage of agile terminology in business practices and organizational structures. Please keep 'em coming!

Mallie Hart Happy to hear it. Agile gave us simplicity. All the answers we need to build adaptable teams, products, and organizations. Somehow it all became over complicated and convoluted again. 

I’m sure someone has come up with a law stating why this happens :)

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Bridging that gap is crucial. Emphasizing collaboration over hierarchy can unlock Scrums full potential across teams!

postsData.content:
𝐒𝐭𝐨𝐩 𝐓𝐫𝐲𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐨 𝐁𝐞 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭—𝐉𝐮𝐬𝐭 𝐁𝐞 𝐘𝐨𝐮

Back in school, I was that person—always trying to say the right thing, do the right thing, be the right kind of person so no one would judge me.

I wanted to seem smart, capable, and in control. But deep down? I was scared. Scared that if I messed up, people would see the cracks.

That if I wasn’t “𝐠𝐨𝐨𝐝 𝐞𝐧𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡" I wouldn’t belong.

So, I hid parts of myself. I overthought every word, every action. I tried to be perfect.

𝐁𝐮𝐭 𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞’𝐬 𝐰𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐈’𝐯𝐞 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝: 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐚 𝐦𝐨𝐯𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐠𝐞𝐭. 𝐘𝐨𝐮’𝐥𝐥 𝐧𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐜𝐡 𝐢𝐭.

- I stopped worrying so much about what others thought.
- I started attracting people who valued the real me.
- I realized that confidence isn’t about seeming perfect—it’s about knowing you don’t have to be.

𝐇𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐟𝐞𝐥𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐰𝐚𝐲? 𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐢𝐝 𝐲𝐨𝐮 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐞 𝐢𝐭?

postsData.content:
Sometimes, the most toxic comments are the quiet ones.

Subtle phrases can be the silent force behind workplace bullying.

Here are a few that may seem harmless but leave a lasting impact:

1/ "You're overthinking this."

Translation: Your concerns don’t matter.

2/ "I'll just do it myself."

Translation: I don’t trust you as a professional.

3/ "I guess this is the best you could do."

Translation: Your effort isn’t enough.

4/ "We all have families, but..."

Translation: Your personal life doesn’t matter.

5/ "Later..."

Translation: Your input can wait—or be ignored.

6/ "Don’t take it personally, but..."

Translation: I’m about to make it personal.

7/ "I don’t have time to explain."

Translation: I won’t help you understand.

8/ "Maybe next time."

Translation: I don’t like your ideas.

9/ "I was joking; don’t take it seriously."

Translation: I’m disguising hurtful comments as humor.

10/ "Let’s not make a big deal out of this."

Translation: I don’t care about your issue.

11/ "We don’t need to reinvent the wheel."

Translation: Stop suggesting improvements.

12/ "..."

Translation: I'm ignoring your presence entirely.

These phrases may seem harmless,
but they’re a form of silent bullying that destroys company culture.

A healthy team thrives on respect, open dialogue, and mutual support.

Toxic teams, however, need constant translation in communication.

So, which culture will you choose?

15 Ways to Give Juniors a Chance:

(because 95% of jobs can be taught)

Your next high performer is being rejected because of 'experience requirements'.

Stop this madness.

1. Ditch the 3-5 year experience trap for entry-level roles:
↳ Experience doesn't predict performance. Potential does.

2. Sports and side hustles show more potential than degrees:
↳ Real-world hustle beats theory every time.

3. Start interviews with: "What did you teach yourself last month?"
↳ The best predictor of future growth is past curiosity.

4. Hire for learning speed and curiosity:
↳ Fast, eager learners outperform experience.

5. Ditch the "hit the ground running." Give them a 90-day roadmap:
↳ The fastest way to grow is a clear plan.

6. Let juniors mentor seniors – they know what's next:
↳ The future belongs to digital natives. Let them lead it.

7. Celebrate failures that led to learning – they're future wins:
↳ Every mistake is a lesson your competition hasn't learned yet.

8. Normalize saying "I don't know yet":
↳ The smartest people are comfortable not knowing.

9. Start meetings with: "Here's what I learned this week."
↳ Learning cultures outperform knowing cultures.

10. If someone has the right attitude, invest in their training:
↳ Attitude is everything. The rest can be taught.

11. Let talent take big risks – mentors are the safety nets:
↳ Safe paths never led to extraordinary results.

12. In reviews and 1:1s, ask, "How did you grow?"
↳ Growth mindset > Fixed skill set.

13. Juniors spot opportunities others miss – give them a voice:
↳ Fresh perspectives solve problems experience can't see.

14. Your top performers aren't always the best teachers:
↳ Double your talent by rewarding both doing and teaching.

15. Make "teaching others" a promotion criterion:
↳ Leaders who teach create more leaders.

Stop asking for experience.
Start creating it.

Your next star is waiting. Give them a chance.

postsData.name:
Allard Buijze
Allard Buijze
postsData.content:
That wooshing sound of a deadline flying by. I'm sure we're all familiar with it. But how far along the "todo" list were you by then?

It seems like projects will always exceed their deadlines and budgets. Software projects are notorious for "meeting" their deadlines when the delivery isn't even halfway. If you think about it, it's not that strange. In many software projects, we're doing something for the first time with a group of people we don't know for a customer who doesn't know what they really want.

Last week, during a discussion with colleagues, we stumbled upon the challenge of predicting how long something takes. Developers love estimating their work because it's always clear what needs to be built and under what conditions, and we've done exactly that dozens of times before. Not...

Agile methodologies tried playing into this uncertainty by breaking up long projects into smaller cycles. Even then, Scrum's typical 2-week cycle is too long. We still can't clearly estimate how much work we can do in those two weeks. Why? Nobody can clearly state 𝘸𝘩𝘢𝘵 needs to be built.

I love this about Event Modeling. I've said it before, and I'll say it again. It focuses very nicely on all the details of what needs to be built. Instead of vague descriptions, open for much interpretation, it provides a structured, detailed outline of the steps a system needs to take to finish a certain task.

Does that make Event Modeling the holy grail of estimating work? Unfortunately not. A message that denotes communication with an external system will still involve much more work than a message that represents an internal action.

Event Models can be split into slices. One slice is the state-change slice, which takes a user action, converts it into a command, and produces one or more events. Another is the state-view slice, which takes events, updates information and provides that to—for example—a user interface. Lastly, there is the automation slice. It takes information and produces a command that may result in one or more events.

Slices are small and have very few side effects. Any side effects are mostly visualized as additional slices elsewhere. This makes Event Modeling's "slice" a great "unit of work." The boundaries are clear, and the dependencies of other slices are well-defined.

Does that mean we can sell an event-modeled project for a fixed price? Well, perhaps not. Personally, I think the slices allow us to build much more sensible units of progress that we can measure during a project. We'll be able to compare our progress of slices to the speed at which the deadline nears. And as you get better at it, you can start predicting how long things will take.

Maybe, one day, we'll hear the woosh of a deadline while we're already celebrating the project's successful delivery...

How, if at all, do you measure progress?

comments.commentText:
I had pretty good results using statistical forecasting https://blog.lunarlogic.com/2016/how-we-estimate-at-lunar-logic/. The biggest issue though was having initial input.

Even Modeling slices would be great replacement for user stories in this approach. Yet still historical information of how much time per slice it takes would vary between teams and team members.

In my case I used it on a project already ongoing, so I could get the input for the statistical model from past stories.

Lucjan Wilczewski The problem I've experienced with statistical forecasting is that story points make a lousy "currency" for estimation. The inflation associated with them is quite unpredictable.
My feeling is that slices provide a better unit based on which we can estimate. Might not be the best (there is still some variation), but definitely better than stories and their points.

Allard Buijze I agree with the risk of inflation. I am not a fan of story points, especially there were studies comparing if counting stories number given worse results than using story points. Seemed that quality of predictions was similar. So I assumed 1 SP per story.
We've been running our business for fixed cost based on slices for nearly a decade. It works better than hourly rate for sure for everyone involved.

Adam Dymitruk I thought I had read that somewhere. How do you deal with slices that represent external system interaction? Do they "statistically disappear" among the other slices, or do you have another way to estimate/price those?

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights on Event Modeling! It truly helps clarify project requirements. Measuring progress in slices sounds like a game changer! 🚀

postsData.content:
SUSPECT DEVICE: AI systems with unacceptable risk are now banned in the EU. What risk, we ask.

The EU actually answers that, sort of.

"Unacceptable risk" AI is Class 4, and Class 3, which is not banned but regulated, includes AI systems for recommending medical treatment. Fair enough; medical anything tends to be regulated, and there's no reason not to subject medical AI to standards and tests.

Under Class 4, banned outright, we see:

* AI used for social scoring, where the social scores are applied outside the context in which they are calculated - e.g. firing someone because of their Reddit posts
* Inferring a person's likelihood to commit a crime unless you are the police and already have the criminal banged up because you think they done it
* Subliminal advertising, which doesn't work anyway
* Something so broad that it encompasses all advertising, which will be interesting
* Anything that can infer someone's emotional state
* Biometric analysis except when the government really wants to

postsData.name:
Meera Remani
Meera Remani
postsData.content:
15 Ways to Balance Life and Career 

(without burning out or looking uncommitted)

You’ve seen it happen:
↳ The high performer who burns out and fades away.
↳ The hard worker who stays invisible by never speaking up.
↳ The ambitious one who’s secretly exhausted but afraid to say no.

So can you keep excelling without exhausting yourself?

Yes there is.
Here's your playbook for excellence without exhaustion:

1/ Stop Competing on Availability. Compete on Value.
↳ Being always responsive = replaceable.
↳ High-impact work = trust.
↳ Try this: Deliver results, not instant replies.

2/ Balance Isn’t a One-Time Fix. It’s a Daily Choice.
↳ You don’t “achieve” balance - you choose it daily.
↳ Ask yourself: Is this how I want to spend my time?

3/ Master the Art of Visibility Without Overwork.
↳ Hard work alone isn’t enough - visibility matters.
↳ Try this: “Here’s what’s done, what’s next,
and where I need input.”

4/ Protect Your Energy Like a CEO.
↳ If leaders prioritize thinking time, so should you.
↳ Block deep work hours like an unmissable meeting.

5/ Own Your Priorities, Not Just Your To-Do List.
↳ If you don’t set your priorities, someone else will.
↳ Ask: If I could do one thing today, what should it be?

6/ Learn to Say No - Without Actually Saying No.
↳ No doesn’t make you difficult - it makes you strategic.
↳ Try this: “I can do this, but X will have to wait.
Does that work?”

7/ Automate, Delegate, or Eliminate What Drains You.
↳ More hours ≠ more impact. Smart work > Hard work.
↳ Ask: Can a tool do this? Can someone else?
Does this need to happen?

8/ Don’t Just Manage Time - Manage Attention.
↳ Time management fails if focus is scattered.
↳ Minimize distractions. Batch tasks. Protect deep work.

9/ Set a Standard for How People Work With You.
↳ You train people by what you tolerate.
↳ Try this: “I check emails between X and Y.” Stick to it.

10/ Work as If You’re Training Someone to Replace You.
↳ Leaders delegate, document, and build systems.
↳ Try this: Train others, systematize,
free yourself for bigger things.

11/ If You Want Balance, Stop Trying to "Have It All."
↳ "Having it all" is a myth - prioritize what matters now.
↳ Ask: What’s most important in this season of life?

12/ Detach From Urgency Culture.
↳ Not everything is a fire drill.
↳ Ask: What’s the real deadline?
Push back on false urgency.

13/ Use Constraints to Work More Efficiently.
↳ Work expands to fit time - set limits.
↳ Try this: Cut deadlines in half, focus harder.

14/ Think in Systems, Not Just Tasks.
↳ Don’t repeat - optimize.
↳ Ask: How can I automate or delegate this?

15/ Audit Your Calendar Regularly.
↳ What’s scheduled gets done - but should it be?
↳ Remove unnecessary meetings. Batch tasks.
Reclaim time.

If you could eliminate one unnecessary work habit from your life, what would it be?

️ Share and support your network.
 Follow Meera Remani for impactful leadership insights.

Employee engagement continues to be an issue broadly for many companies. 

So much of it continues to come back to expectation setting, providing an environment for growth and deploying effective management — no small feat regardless of team/company size.

The people aspects of business will always be messy and somewhat complicated, simply because people are. Compound this with the reality that business needs change often, especially in the current work environment. That affects roles, processes, and technology. ‍

Best practices can take you pretty far, but you have to also make room for ongoing modification. < I think this where a lot of companies miss the boat. ️

We are all still trying to grapple with the massive disruption of where and how people work that we’ve seen over the last few years. Digging out and finding what works will take time. ⏳

What do you think — is there more to this?

Replace the ones who don’t fit.

If a tree never shed its leaves, new ones couldn’t grow.

Sometimes you have to embrace turnover to make room for fresh talent:

Great leaders know holding on to people who don't fit anymore doesn't help anyone.

It doesn’t help:

↳ The team.
↳ The company.
↳ Or the person themself.

Sure, turnover can hurt in the short term.

But it's necessary:

↳To bring in new perspectives.
↳Upgrade skills.
↳Align more closely with your goals.
↳And infuse fresh energy into the team.

When it's time to make a change, leaders know it:

 Continual performance issues
 Toxic behavior or poor attitude

 Resistance to change

Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Data Science & Robotics
postsData.content:
Deepseek R1 is shaking up the AI race.

How?

It delivers near-O1 performance—at 1/27th the cost.

Let’s break it down:

↳ Architecture: The Sparse MoE Advantage

Deepseek R1 uses a Sparse Mixture of Experts (MoE) model with a double reinforcement learning approach.
• Unlike O1, R1 relies less on supervised training, meaning it learns autonomously from its mistakes.
• Grok-1 from xAI follows a similar approach, favoring reasoning over a dense-first design.
• OpenAI’s O1, however, combines reinforcement learning with supervised training from models like GPT-4o.

↳ Why R1? It’s 27x Cheaper than O1

The real game-changer: cost efficiency.

Input token cost per million:
• Deepseek R1 → $0.14 (cached), $0.55 (non-cached)
•OpenAI O1 → $7.50 (cached), $15.00 (non-cached)
Output token cost per million:
• Deepseek R1 → $2.19
• OpenAI O1 → $60.00

↳ Distillation: Open-Source Flexibility

R1 can be distilled into smaller models—and they’re already available on Ollama.
• You can run 1.5B to 7B versions of R1 locally.
• OpenAI O1? No distillation yet—only O1 Mini.

↳ Reasoning & Prompting Optimization

R1’s research suggests zero-shot prompting outperforms few-shot for reasoning models.
• Being more direct in prompts enhances the model’s logical capabilities.

↳ How Does R1 Compare to O1?

Codeforces Percentile:
• Deepseek R1 → 96.3
• OpenAI O1 → 96.6
Math & SWE Reasoning Tasks:
• Deepseek R1 → 79.8 (AIME 2024), 97.3 (MATH 500)
• OpenAI O1 → 79.2 (AIME 2024), 96.4 (MATH 500)

R1 holds its own against O1—and even outperforms it in math and software engineering tasks.

What This Means for the Future of AI
• R1 proved that reasoning models don’t have to be expensive.
• With R1’s open-source push, OpenAI may be forced to make O1 more accessible.
• R1 is open-source: more developers and labs can build on top of it to build cheap and powerful models.

Deepseek R1 changed everything.

Now, what does this mean for you? I wrote a full deep dive here: charafeddine[dot]co

Make sure to subscribe to receive your letter.
